item.title: Mutualistic Flourishing: 2021 to 2022
item.description: Taken on 08.31.2021 Taken on 09.03.2021 Taken on 09.10.2021 In Alaska, life flourishes both on land and in the sea because of mutualistic relationships (lichen + fungi + barnacles) from my photos. This post is a space for my annual reflection, where I look back at the theme I chose last year and set an intention for a theme for the new year.

item.title: the mid-twenties
item.description: This post was originally published on my newsletter. This was also my 1st installment in my 100 mini-essays experiment. a colorful storefront I found in Buenos Aires (more at my instagram) So I turned 24 yesterday and the biggest question on my mind (as it seems to have incepted all of my friends’ minds) is: does 24 count as “mid-twenties”? “Welcome to your mid-twenties” my friends quip.

item.title: Gambling on Dreams
item.description: A vibration ripples out from my phone. It’s a message from a classmate asking about my rooming plans for next semester with a not-so-subtle suggestion at a better option. I’m nearing the end of my first year in college, and having been successful at my quest to fit in, I’m tempted to change as little as possible to keep the good things going. The proposal to room with someone new (who I knew from the very intimate experience of recognizing their face across the dining hall every once in a while) was both an opportunity and a risk.

item.title: Discovering a New Year
item.description: Exploration—the relinquishing of the old for something new and unknown. Why do we explore? What drives us to leave behind cozy homes, comfortable routines, and familiar lands, foods, and faces to seek out the new and unknown?

item.title: Stupid Scholars, the Power of Hands, and Free Lunches: Riding Through 4 Years of University
item.description: “It’ll be fine,” I reassured myself for what seemed like the millionth time. The mere prospect of a roller coaster ride had reduced me to a broken record. I’ve never been a follower of the camp that derives thrill, much less joy, from artificial fear. Horror movies are a hard no, especially at night, alone in my room, and maybe it’s obvious, but I had never ridden a roller coaster.
